Marble Mayhem: Fragile Ball is just a casual, 2D puzzle game that really reminds me of one of the toys that have similar functionality I used to have. This game contains 100 levels that may seem easy at first, but some of them can be difficult, providing you rather quite a challenge. The way you play is that you move your mouse to the left or right to rotate the screen for the marble to move in order to get from point A to point B.

But it's not something as simple as getting from point A to point B, you also have to maneuver through obstacles that comes your way. You would have to avoid hitting spikes that exists in some levels and falling down too far to the point the marble shatters. The levels shouldn't be too difficult, but if you don't succeed, try try again!

The graphics and the game interface aren't really the best, but not like it really matters. Oh and there's trading cards too if you want to craft more badges.

Should you buy this game? If you're just looking for a casual game, like 2D puzzles, or just wanting to make more badges from trading cards, then yes. Just give it a shot anyways! :)

reviewText:
I'm always keen to try out a new marble madness-esque game. Fragile Ball is basic 2D 'marble' game of skill, with one simple goal of using gravity to get your ball to the exit, while avoiding the inevitable traps. Certainly sounds simple, but in practice its one hell of a challenge!

Hard is perhaps an understatement. Level design plays a big role in this, with plenty of hazards to avoid, placed in just the right spots to have you pulling out your hair. Some level design reminded me of the old classic, Crazy Machines, where one small incorrect move and it all falls apart in milliseconds, followed by a swift restart while you mumble to yourself that you can do better. There are also other levels though that are more open/scrolling, but regardless of the level type the restarts will be many! It can be brutal .. I found myself swearing & groaning at my screen on more than one occasion. I do enjoy a challenge though; something that takes practice.

With the high level of difficulty, I find this game is best suited to short sessions. 5-10mins over a coffee in the morning is good to wake the brain up. If I get stuck for too long, I stop to prevent the frustration building.

Along with more 'standard' levels previously mentioned, there are also some maze levels to challenge you. These are generally bigger levels allowing a larger degree rotation. Standard levels generally limit the range of angle you can choose giving more of a fixed direction - but this does vary quite a bit. Graphics are rather bland, along with animations and menus, but they do the job.

Although I do like the game overall, there are a few things that bugged me that I think could be improved upon. The mouse sensitivity has a limited range on the slider. With my Logitech mouse & slider all the way down, the movement still was too sensitive for my liking. This restricted the precision over the ball, but on reflection I can't be 100% sure if its just the mouse sensitivity or harsh physics in the game design.

Also found the maze levels when run in full screen made me feel nauseous. The spinning speed (and almost constant spinning sometimes), particularly when view full screen gave me some motion sickness. In a smaller screen (you can play in windowed mode) it was ok for me. Something to warn people about if they are sensitive to such things. Most levels were ok, but a few were tough to deal with.

Running in window mode was a bit problematic as well, as the mouse didn't lock to the game screen. I would move my mouse too far & it would flick back to windows, killing control over the ball.

I wouldn't recommend this to everyone (some will just find it infuriating!). It's not the best example I have seen in the genre with some flaws, but you are a gamer with patience & persistence, who likes a hardcore challenge then this is a good value puzzler to add to your collection.

reviewText:
Simple concept, but more fun than I expected.

At its core, it reminds me of those old Marble Labyrinth Tilt games. You have a ball and you must tilt the screen using your mouse to make it reach it's destination. All while avoiding spikes, traps, and falling from significant heights. (It is a FRAGILE ball after all).

Seriously, some levels are frustrating but you get a sense of satisfaction when you complete it.
I'm only about 1/3 complete at the time of this review and the levels are already daunting, but in a fun way.

If you enjoy casual games with a bit more challenge than the norm, give this a try.

reviewText:
This is not my normal type of game but it had some fun with it.

It is a physics game (think Angry Birds) where you move a ball around on a 2D map you move with your mouse. Sometimes you get a fragile ball that will shatter if it hits anything too hard. Sometimes you get a blue bouncy ball that doesn't shatter but bounces more. Sometimes there are cannons you can enter to be propelled out. Spacebar or left clicking will reset your puzzle for you. There is a normal and hard mode. I tried the normal mode and found some puzzles to be very easy and some very challenging. So far I have done 13 of the 100 levels available. Between each puzzle you are treated to a 10x10 grid where you can select the next puzzle. Each completed puzzle unlocks one or two nearby squares much like the old MicroSoft game, Minesweeper. I have not encountered any bugs, glitches, DRM, or errors.

There are three sets of options:
Video Options: Fullscreen toggle, Anti-aliasing toggle, Video Resolution 640x480 800x600 1024x768 1280x800, V-sync toggle
Sound Options: Background music volume slider bar, Sound Effect volume slider bar
Control Options: Rotation Speed slider bar
Here is a gameplay video of it (sorry about the quality): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xR0R1MWd1zU

Eh, I did find this game okay, so I would recommend this to others to just give it a shot. :)

Marble Mayhem: Fragile Ball is just a casual, 2D puzzle game that really reminds me of one of the toys that have similar functionality I used to have. This game contains 100 levels that may seem easy at first, but some of them can be difficult, providing you rather quite a challenge. The way you play is that you move your mouse to the left or right to rotate the screen for the marble to move in order to get from point A to point B.

But it's not something as simple as getting from point A to point B, you also have to maneuver through obstacles that comes your way. You would have to avoid hitting spikes that exists in some levels and falling down too far to the point the marble shatters. The levels shouldn't be too difficult, but if you don't succeed, try try again!

The graphics and the game interface aren't really the best, but not like it really matters. Oh and there's trading cards too if you want to craft more badges.

Should you buy this game?
If you're just looking for a casual game, like 2D puzzles, or just wanting to make more badges from trading cards, then yes. Just give it a shot anyways! :)

This is an excellent and simple puzzle game where the goal is simple: You control a marble, and you must get it to the end of the level.

But your marble is quite fragile..... so you have to be gentle with the marble too, or else it'll break. This game mechanic makes Marble Mayhem: Fragile Ball a VERY hard game, but it stays very addictive.

The game has Steam cards, which is a GOOD thing.

The soundtrack is calm and it fits well with the game. I especially love the level select song myself.

Graphics are alright. Who needs great HD extreme graphics in a puzzle game anyways? :3

Controls are responsive, and it uses the arrows keys or the mouse to rotate the level. It plays very smooth with the mouse, and smoothness in a marble game is very important.


I have one complaint: No level editor. I mean, with how simple the game is, a level editor for it would be very easy to make and to use. And I want to be honest here: I WISH THERE WAS A LEVEL EDITOR. This game is just so good, a level editor would make it PERRRRRRRRRRRRRFECT. A way to share levels by other users (Workshop) would be great too if a level editor feature ever happens.



Overall, I highly recommend this game. With a low price and an addictive gameplay, its totally worth it.

While I can say I recommend the game for what it is - a simple get the ball from point A to point B by tilting the screen with your mouse or keyboard arrow keys, I can't recommend it for the feeling of nausea I felt while playing it. I gave it about 20 minutes and got through 12 or so levels - while they were challenging and fun - the way the screen tilts with the board made me wish I was near a toilet while playing.

Graphics are okay for the genre - pushing towards realism, but in reality the game would have been acceptable with black lines and a white ball instead of going for the full 3D rendered effects.

Controls are done with the left and right motion of the mouse, or with the left and right arrow keys on the keyboard. I don't know about controller support, but regardless you could probably macro a controller to work with this game no problem.

Audio was loud and horrible. Had to mute the audio to play the game.

reviewText:
Have you ever dreamed of rolling a frustratingly delicate ball around garbage maps made from the clearance section of your local Home Depot, all while listening to music that wouldn't be out of place in that weird Italian restaurant no one ever ate at but inconspicuously stayed open all through your childhood (You know the one, the parking lot was always empty save for that one car that never moved)? Well boy golly, have I got good news for you! Your dreams can come true today, yes all that I mentioned above, with the added bonus of the ball being so fragile you could swear it‚Äôs made from the purest of frozen orphan tears. Now I know, you're probably exhilarated, but contain your enthusiasm, because there's more. The engine has almost no concept of friction, so the slightest twitch sends that little ball flying through the air like a majestic, infuriating eagle, almost certain to detonate on impact when it lands a mere 15 inches away. The lack of friction is especially rewarding when the level has tiny, moving platforms, which require you to have the hand dexterity of a Himalayan Monk.

Seriously though, if you're into really difficult, repetitive puzzles/mazes/pachinko-with-the-added-threat-of-death type roll the ball games, this game can actually be pretty fun. Aesthetically, it looks like a demo for a game that's still in development, with textures and level design being reused so frequently the deja-vu gave me a concussion. The font is reminiscent of a Chuck E Cheese pizza menu only instead of a birthday party with that cool tube-gym with that awesome twisty slide you get pain and a chance to try out those cool curse words you‚Äôve been waiting to use.

6/10, would suggest waiting until its on-sale
